item.title: Ticket #3824 (Transition the Admin Area over to using jQuery) updated
item.dc:creator: aercolino
item.description:
how to install jquery/interface in wordpress 2.1 (admin)

wp-admin/index.php: 

17a18
> wp_enqueue_script('interface');

wp-admin/page-new.php: 

7a8
> wp_enqueue_script('interface');

wp-admin/page.php: 

56a57
> 	wp_enqueue_script('interface');

wp-admin/post-new.php: 

7a8
> wp_enqueue_script('interface');

wp-admin/post.php: 

59a60
> 	wp_enqueue_script('interface');

wp-includes/script-loader.php: 

32a33,34
> 		$this->add( 'jquery', '/wp-includes/js/jquery/jquery.js', false, '1.1.1');
> 		$this->add( 'interface', '/wp-includes/js/jquery/interface.js', array('jquery'), '1.1.1');

item.dc:creator: foolswisdom
item.description:

Remember to give good Summary's

item.title: Ticket #3826 (TinyMCE misconfiguration causes erronous tag replacements) created
item.dc:creator: novasource
item.description:
If this code is stored in the database: 

<li>
<div class="g2image_float_right"><wpg2id>6355</wpg2id></div>
<p><strong>some boldfaced text</strong> Other text.</li>

the editor converts it to this when you open it in an editor: 

	<li>
<p class="g2image_float_right"><wpg2id></wpg2id>6355
<strong>some boldfaced text</strong> Other text.</li>

The editor stripped the div tags, put the div tags' content inside the p tags, and assigned the div's class to the p.

item.title: Ticket #3825 (problem with conflict of permalinks in multiple instalations) created
item.dc:creator: thomask
item.description:
confirmed bug in 2.1, was not in older versions, see ​http://wordpress.org/support/topic/106386?replies=2

I got two separate wordpress instalation ​http://www.kapler.cz ​http://www.kapler.cz/tibetska-doga

when I run permalinks only on the first one, it works fine, but when i turn permalinks on also on the second one, it "jumps" to the 404 page (with right path e.g. ​http://www.kapler.cz/tibetska-doga/my-article-name but with layout (template, header..) of the first instalation.

I have just did reinsatalation of the second blog to 2.1, prior this reinstalation the permalinks were working normaly. I tried to delete both .htaccess and make permalinks live again, but nothing helps.

item.title: Ticket #3820 (Squid in accelerator mode; Permalink "mod_rewrite" problem.) updated
item.dc:creator: foolswisdom
item.description:
Priority, Severity, Milestone changed

shanefroebel, thank you for participating in WordPress! As WordPress uses the same or very similar mod write rules as other blogging systems, I would be surprised if the fault is WordPress'.

I don't really understand the nature of these problems, but someone on IRC suggested "try 404 handler. probably PATH_INFO is mangled on your side"

Realistically, if the problem is WordPress' it is unlikely be be resolved unless you are able to isolate the problem further.

item.title: Ticket #3822 (Editor shows incorrect vertical spacing with Firefox 2.0.0.3) created
item.dc:creator: novasource
item.description:
When editing with Firefox, the enter key produces about 3-4 vertical spaces. Sometimes, but not always, this appears to correctly end up as a <p>.

If I save a draft and reload it, vertical spacing is correct. However, if I click on Code and go back to Visual, the incorrect vertical spacing is sometimes restored.

This problem was duplicated in Firefox 2.0.0.1 with a fresh install of WordPress per ​3814.

item.title: Ticket #3821 (Several formatting buttons in editor do not work in Fx 2.0.0.3) created
item.dc:creator: novasource
item.description:
I just did a fresh reinstall of WordPress 2.1 per ​3814. When editing a post, the following buttons do not work:

  • bold
  • italics
  • strikethrough
  • ul
  • ol

In each case, pressing the button appears to apply the style and then immediately revert it.

item.title: Ticket #3820 (Squid in accelerator mode; Permalink "mod_rewrite" problem.) created
item.dc:creator: shanefroebel
item.description:
Yesterday I installed squid on our main domain, battlestarwiki.org. And our WordPress (Version 2.2), installed at blog.battlestarwiki.org, falls under the domain. When I went to "click" on a link, it brings me back to the "main" index.

​http://blog.battlestarwiki.org/2007/02/19/ahoy-matty-i-got-me-a-squid/ is a perfect example. Clicking on the link, does not allow me to view the single post by itself.

We have Mediawiki installed and it works just fine with mod_rewrite.

Thanks for your time. :-)

item.title: Ticket #3819 (New Comment Moderation: better buttons) created
item.dc:creator: docwhat
item.description:
When you go to approve, delete or spam a comment, the page that asks you to confirm says something like "You are about to approve the following comment: ... Are you sure you want to do that?" and then shows a pair of "[Yes]" "[No]" buttons.

Even better would be something like:

You are about to approve the following comment: ...

[Approve this comment] [Don't approve now]

The problem with the Yes & No buttons is that the user has to notice or remember what the question is. If the user clicks on delete but thinks that they clicked on approve, they will pick "yes".

Another alternative, is to show all the options for the comment in one place and only highlight the option selected from the email. This would let the user get used to "delete" being the 2nd of three choices and hit the right one.

Ciao!

item.title: Ticket #1392 (Summary should be recognizable as such in RSS feed) closed
item.dc:creator: rob1n
item.description:
wontfix:

The summary, by RSS definition (not sure about Atom) is text-only, which means no HTML. You can achieve the effect you're looking for by using full-content feeds (and thus HTML), and adding <!--more-->'s.

item.title: Ticket #3818 (Akismet navigation generated mySQL error) created
item.dc:creator: vlogtheimpaler
item.description:
I just stumbled across this while paging through comments captured via Akismet. Not sure if it's perfectly reproducible but you'll need at least 2 pages of captured spam (51+ spam comments). I could not find a duplicate of this in trac so here's the breakdown:

Step 1. Navigate to page 2 of comments marked as spam. Step 2. Using the supplied links on the page, navigate back to page 1 Step 3. Witness a WordPress Database Error message which appears something like the following:

WordPress database error: [You have an error in your SQL syntax; check the manual that corresponds to your MySQL server version for the right syntax to use near '-50, 0' at line 1] SELECT * FROM PREFIX_comments WHERE comment_approved = 'spam' ORDER BY comment_date DESC LIMIT -50, 0

No results found.

However it still manages to report that "There are currently 76 comments identified as spam." but does not display the list of the previous spam comments.

the MySQL version on this server is 5.0.18 running under PHP 5.

item.title: Ticket #3814 (Editor unusable in FireFox 2.0.0.1) updated
item.dc:creator: novasource
item.description:
I had two plugins installed: Google Toolbar and DOM Inspector (the later delivered by Mozilla). I uninstalled both plugins and still have the same problem. From the time the Write page first appears, it takes 19 seconds for the edit box to finally appear. Everything else about this entire site is quite snappy except for the editor.

This is happening with FF 2.0.0.1 on a Windows Vista box on a major university network and on a Windows XP box on a home network with 1.5Mb/s DSL.

item.dc:creator: juergen
item.description:
$ svk diff //wordpress/trunk/wp-includes/js/tinymce/tiny_mce_config.php wp-includes/js/tinymce/tiny_mce_config.php
=== tiny_mce_config.php
==================================================================
--- tiny_mce_config.php (/wordpress/trunk/wp-includes/js/tinymce/tiny_mce_config.php)   (revision 6581)
+++ tiny_mce_config.php (/wordpress/local/wp-includes/js/tinymce/tiny_mce_config.php)   (local)
@@ -1,5 +1,6 @@
 <?php
        @ require('../../../wp-config.php');
+       cache_javascript_headers();
        function wp_translate_tinymce_lang($text) {
                if ( ! function_exists('__') ) {

item.title:
Ticket #3815 (Editor adds

tags where not needed) created
item.dc:creator: novasource
item.description: In IE 7, the editor surrounds list items (things between <li> tags) with <p> tags upon manual save and reload of the page. E.g., <li>text</li> becomes <li><p>text</p></li>.

item.title: Ticket #3814 (Editor unusable in FireFox 2.0.0.1) created
item.dc:creator: novasource
item.description:
When creating a blank, new page using FireFox 2.0.0.1, the following problems happen:
-Editor takes a very long time to appear.
-Editor starts with visual tab selected, but not buttons appear.
-Clicking on Code has no effect.
-Clicking on Visual makes the formatting buttons appear.
-Formatting buttons have no effect.
-Clicking Save causes the "Are you sure you want to navigate away from this page?" dialog to appear.
-Pressing OK on aforementioned dialog causes the new post to apparently appear as a draft, but when returning to that draft post, any content previously typed does not appear. (Checking the preview window below confirms that the post has lost all text since the last edit.)

item.title: Ticket #3813 (Editing text formatting in IE 7 causes "Are you sure you want to ...) created
item.dc:creator: novasource
item.description: Editing text formatting in IE 7 causes "Are you sure you want to navigate away from this page?" dialog. E.g., select a word and hit the B (boldface) button.

item.title: Ticket #3698 (Matching more tags eats up too much content) updated
item.dc:creator: McShelby
item.description: Thanks, now I get it. I can not say that this is very intuitive to me but that's just my biased opinion. Nevertheless, the regex fix from post.patch should also be applied to post-template.php. Or am I wrong again?

item.title: Ticket #1421 (<!--more--> logic should be a filter) updated
item.dc:creator: McShelby
item.description: Probably we need a new filter for stripping the <!--more--> tag that applies during get_the_content(). By that this will not break plugins that rely on the <!--more--> tag to be stripped away during a call to get_the_content().

item.title: Ticket #3698 (Matching more tags eats up too much content) updated
item.dc:creator: foolswisdom
item.description:
Replying to McShelby:

Why is the regex designed to match any arbitrary character after the "more" keyword?

"customize the More… link for each post split by the <!--more--> tag" ​http://wordpress.com/blog/2006/08/02/but-wait-theres-more/

item.title: more.patch attached to Ticket #3698
item.dc:creator: McShelby

item.title: Ticket #3698 (Matching more tags eats up too much content) reopened
item.dc:creator: McShelby
item.description:
I am just wondering about the regex in general and the patch in specific.

Why is the regex designed to match any arbitrary character after the "more" keyword? From my point of view this only makes sense if WP wants to support XHTML styled "more" tags like <!--more/-->. At the moment I can put a HTML comment into the post like <!--more information below--> which will accidently be treated as a "more" tag.

To avoid the above and to support XHTML styled "more" tags, the regex should be changed to '<!--more\s*(?:\/)?-->/'

Also post.patch was only applied to post.php and not to post-template.php. Was this as intended?

Patch for the proposed changes to post.php and post-template.php is attached.

item.title: Ticket #3712 (Blogroll Import Links fails) updated
item.dc:creator: drmike
item.description:
Cc, Priority changed

Greets:

Please be aware that this problem also occurs on the standard WordPress Multiuser platform as well as wordpress.com.

​http://en.forums.wordpress.com/topic.php?id=6982

It only occurs though when one is trying to upload the XML file. Importing links via a URL works fine.

Hope this helps, -drmike

item.title: Ticket #3811 (Sorting bookmarks within categories) closed
item.dc:creator: Bairman
item.description:
worksforme:

Replying to Otto42:

​http://codex.wordpress.org/Template_Tags/wp_list_bookmarks

Look closely at the "orderby" parameter.

Thanks... I saw your post in the support forum too. I guess I'll close this ticket then, unless the developers decide to add the feature back to the admin panel. It'd be a bit easier to implement that way, especially for non-coders.

wontfix:

I don't see the issue... PHP code won't be executed in comments, unless you have a death wish, and it doesn't automatically escape <'s and >'s in the comments.

item.dc:creator: westi
item.description:
duplicate:

Duplicate of #3811

item.title: Ticket #3812 (Blogroll: Can no longer sort by rank) created
item.dc:creator: ydeologi
item.description:
I'm running a 2.1 blog. In the admin, I can't find where to change how links are displayed.

My template uses get_links_list, which calls the list fine, but the 3 links I have are displayed in the same order, no matter if I rank them 1, 2, 3 or 3, 2, 1.

In Blogroll -> Manage Blogroll, you can change how they're displayed in the admin, but evidently not on the site?

In 2.0<, it used to be an option as displayed here: ​http://codex.wordpress.org/Links_Manager

...but no more?

One suggestion in the forums was to try orderby=rating using wp_list_bookmarks, but that function appears to be completely gone as well in 2.1.

Thanks for your help.
